column3: (v.) become less in amount or intensity
column4: Your enthusiasm for skiing might abate after falling off a ski lift and getting a mouthful of snow.

column3: (n.) the use of tricks to deceive someone
column4: This tricky kind of deceit and manipulation is called chicanery.

column3: (v.) cause to become widely known
column4: He said it appeared the killer was inspired by extremist information disseminated over the internet.

column3: (v.) take exception to
column4: Mr Xi can present himself as one of Hu’s ideological successors and nobody dares gainsay him.

column3: (adj.) potentially existing but not presently evident or realized
column4: There's deep-seated concern about immigration, and some of that is latent racism.

column3: (adj.) markedly different from an accepted norm
column4: We are also killing thousands of cougars every year, and this is creating chaos in their societies and promoting some of these aberrant individuals.

column3: (v.) change from a liquid to a thickened or solid state
column4: The next morning, there is coagulated blood under the skin on her breast.

column3: (n.) separation into component parts
column4: The dissolution of your band means you better get started on your solo album.

column3: (adj.) full of trivial conversation
column4: A garrulous person just won’t stop talking (and talking, and talking, and talking...).

column3: (v.) praise, glorify, or honor
column4: They were being lauded as perhaps the best basketball team ever.

column3: (v.) stab or urge on as if with a pointed stick
column4: The drunken posturing is more than enough to provoke reactions from local police, and to goad more determined opposition into action.

column3: (n.) temporary cessation or suspension
column4: Odor and Bautista have appealed their discipline, which will be held in abeyance pending a resolution.

column3: (n.) the closing section of a musical composition
column4: A coda is a concluding segment of a piece of music, a dance, or a statement.

column3: (n.) disagreeable sounds
column4: Disagreeable sounds can be called dissonance.

column3: (adj.) deficient in alertness or activity
column4: Gray appeared “lethargic” but was breathing normally and didn’t appear to need a hospital, Porter said.

column3: (v) run away
column4: Sanchez was being sought after he absconded from parole.

column3: (adj.) powerfully persuasive
column4: When you make a cogent argument, it means your argument is clear and persuasive.

column3: (v.) cause to expand as it by internal pressure
column4: A soda and pizza binge might make your stomach distend, meaning your stomach will swell as a result of pressure from the inside.

column3: (v.) an impression in a surface, as made by a blow
column4: To gouge can mean to make a hole or dent in something, or to swindle or steal by overcharging.

column3: (n.) an embankment that is built in order to prevent a river from overflowing
column4: Army Corps of Engineers has rated the flood control system as inadequate, in part because of work done on property bordering the levees.

column3: (adj.) marked by temperance in indulgence
column4: A rock musician may sing about enjoying wine and women, but in his private life he may be abstemious.

column3: (adj.) similar in size or degree or extent
column4: Many people think the death penalty is a commensurate punishment for murder. In other words, the penalty fits the crime.

column3: (v.)  undergo condensation
column4: When you distill something, you are boiling it down to its essence — its most important part.

column3: (adj.) lofty in style; puffed up with vanity
column4: Trump was grandiloquent about himself, his temperament and his ability to serve.

column3: (n.) a manner lacking seriousness
column4: Joking that your dead grandmother "never looked better" could inject some levity, or frivolity, into her funeral, but your relatives might find your joke inappropriate to the occasion.

column3: (v.) scold or reprimand; take to task
column4: To admonish is to scold.If you want to show someone you're not happy with his behavior, admonish him. It sounds better than "scolding," and it's less painful than spanking.

column3: (n.) a publication containing a variety of works
column4: When you search an online encyclopedia, you are searching a compendium of information on just about everything.

column3: (v.) move or draw apart
column4: When two roads diverge, they split and go in different directions.

column3: (adj.) temperamentally seeking and enjoying the company of others
column4: If you know someone who's outgoing, sociable, and fond of the company of others, you might want to call her gregarious.

column3: (v.) a segment of the trunk of a tree when stripped of branches
column4: A log is the trunk of a tree minus the branches: logging is cutting down trees. A log is also a written record of something, and logging is keeping such a record.

column3: (v.) make impure by adding a foreign or inferior substance
column4: They found 22 percent were adulterated;

column3: (adj.) showing a cheerful willingness to do favors for others
column4: If only the world were populated entirely with complaisant people!

column3: (v.) take away possessions from someone
column4: It could be your wine portfolio, your stake in a mining company, or even the extra coats that are taking up space in your closet. Whatever it is, when you divest something, you get rid of it.

column3: (adj.) free of deceit
column4: He’s earnest and guileless, which may not make for a believable undercover agent, but who cares?

column3: (adj.) full of trivial conversation
column4: A loquacious person talks a lot, often about stuff that only they think is interesting.

column3: (adj.) characterized by an appreciation of beauty or good taste
column4: A velvet painting of dogs playing poker might have minimal aesthetic appeal.

column3: (adj.) disposed to act in accordance with someone's wishes
column4: If you are willing to submit to someone's request, then you are compliant. Parents like it when their teenagers are compliant and follow the rules. Teenagers, on the other hand, are probably not as compliant as parents would like to think!

column3: (n.) a representation of a person's thinking with symbolic marks
column4: A document is a piece of paper that contains official information.

column3: (adj.) naive and easily deceived or tricked
column4: If you are gullible, the joke is on you because you are easily fooled.

column3: (adj.) transparently clear; easily understandable
column4: Lucid writing is important in journalism, so that readers easily get the point of the article they're reading.

column3: (n.) a sum total of many heterogeneous things taken together
column4: If you're writing a novel, you might create a character who is an aggregate of five or six real people.

column3: (adj.) making or willing to make concessions
column4: If you're in a fight with a friend and you want to end it, you should make a conciliatory gesture, such as inviting her to a party you're having.

column3: (adj.) pertaining to a code of beliefs accepted as authoritative
column4: To be dogmatic is to follow a set of rules no matter what. The rules might be religious, philosophical, or made-up, but dogmatic people would never waver in their beliefs so don’t even think of trying to change their minds.

column3: (n.) a loud bombastic declamation expressed with strong emotion
column4: A harangue is more than a speech, louder than a discussion, and nastier than a lecture. It is a verbal attack that doesn't let up, delivered as a verb or received as a noun. Either way, it's pretty unpleasant.

column3: (adj.) softly bright or radiant
column4: During the winter holidays, with all their emphasis on light, you can see luminous displays of candles everywhere.

column3: (n.) liveliness and eagerness
column4: Someone with alacrity shows cheerful willingness and eager behavior, like a kid whose mother has told him he can buy anything in a candy store.

column3: (vt.) excuse, overlook, or make allowances for
column4: Some teachers condone chewing gum, and some don't.

column3: (adj.) inactive but capable of becoming active
column4: Even dormant black holes warp space and time, scientists now say.

column3: (adj.) all of the same or similar kind or nature
column4: Despite 55 recognized ethnic minorities, China is a broadly homogeneous nation where 91% of the 1.3 billion population are Han Chinese.

column3: (n.) liberality in bestowing gifts; extremely liberal and generous of spirit
column4: He showed great magnanimity in not pressing charges when I drove his car into the pond. "Accidents happen my friend," he said, and patted me on the back.

column3: (v.) provide physical relief, as from pain
column4: Do all these words make your head ache? If so, take an aspirin to alleviate, or relieve, your pain.

column3: (v.) be confusing or perplexing to
column4: If you have an identical twin, you've probably tried dressing alike so that people confound you with, or mistake you for, one another.

column3: (v.) fool or hoax
column4: These cases may establish new legal avenues for investors who claim to have been duped by unscrupulous bankers.

column3: (n.) extravagant exaggeration
column4: Praising your favorite sports team is one thing, but if you call the team the most incredible group of humans ever to walk the earth, then you're going overboard and indulging in hyperbole.

column3: (n.) someone shirking duty by feigning illness or incapacity
column4: Have you ever pretended to be sick or hurt to get out of taking a test or doing a chore? Then you, my dear, are a malingerer, and should be ashamed of yourself. Shape up!

column3: (v.) to bring or combine together or with something else
column4: Institutions — such as banks, schools, or hospitals — often join forces and amalgamate with one other.

column3: (n.) an expert able to appreciate a field
column4: He had become something of a gun connoisseur.

column3: (adj.) joyously unrestrained
column4: More than chipper, more than happy, more than delighted is ebullient — meaning bubbling over with joy and delight.

column3: (adj.) characterized by attack on established beliefs or institutions
column4: At the same theater, for only $35, you can see the iconoclastic British playwright Philip Ridley’s new dark comedy, “Radiant Vermin.”

column3: (adj.) capable of being shaped or bent
column4: A malleable personality is capable of being changed or trained, and a malleable metal is able to be pounded or pressed into various shapes.

column3: (adj.) having more than one possible meaning
column4: If someone sends you an ambiguous text or one filled with typos, the bot might respond “not sure what you mean.”

column3: (n.) the act of competing as for profit or a prize
column4: The teams were in fierce contention for first place.

column3: (adj.) selecting what seems best of various styles or ideas
column4: She listens to hip-hop, Gregorian chant, and folk music from the '60s. He's been seen wearing a handmade tuxedo jacket over a thrift-store flannel shirt. They both have eclectic tastes.

column3: (n.) the worship of idols or images that are not God
column4: Idolatry means the worship of images as if they were gods.

column3: (n.) someone who exhibits great independence in thought and action
column4: Sheen suggested Trump's current success is down to "people responding to something different, fresh, innovative and maverick.

column3: (n.) mixed feelings or emotions
column4: If you love your mom but find her totally embarrassing, you might feel ambivalent about having her give a presentation at your school.

column3: (adj.) showing an inclination to disagree
column4: A contentious issue is one that people are likely to argue about, and a contentious person is someone who likes to argue or fight.

column3: (n.) capacity or power to produce a desired effect
column4: The degree to which a method or medicine brings about a specific result is its efficacy. You might not like to eat it, but you can't question the efficacy of broccoli as a health benefit.

column3: (adj.) not subject or susceptible to change or variation
column4: There are many things in life that are immutable; these unchangeable things include death, taxes, and the laws of physics.

column3: (adj.) given to lying
column4:
A mendacious person is one who tells lies habitually and intentionally. 
He is using a dead man, whose family has pleaded to be left in peace, for a mendacious political attack.

column3: (v.) to make better
column4: You could try introducing a second lollipop to ameliorate a battle between two toddlers over a single lollipop.

column3: (adj.) feeling or expressing pain or sorrow for sins or offenses
column4: We are sorry to inform you that the adjective contrite means regretful, remorseful, or even guilty.

column3: (n.) audacious behavior that you have no right to
column4: When a couple stroll into a crowded restaurant, demand the best table, and threaten the staff unless they're seated right away, that's effrontery.

column3: (v.) make worse or less effective
column4: If you make bad decisions in the morning after drinking coffee, you might conclude that caffeine tends to impair your judgment.

column3: (n.) striking change in appearance or character or circumstances
column4: In Kafka's novel entitled Metamorphosis, a man wakes up to find he has turned into a cockroach.

column3: (n.) something located at a time when it could not have existed
column4: An anachronism is something that doesn't fit its time period, like if you say you'll "dial" your smartphone.

column3: (n.) a difficult problem
column4: The tricky word conundrum is used to describe a riddle or puzzle, sometimes including a play on words or pun.

column3: (n.) a mournful poem; a lament for the dead
column4: An elegy is a sad poem, usually written to praise and express sorrow for someone who is dead. Although a speech at a funeral is a eulogy, you might later compose an elegy to someone you have loved and lost to the grave.

column3: (adj.) having or revealing little emotion or sensibility
column4: Someone who doesn't seem to react — who is always "taking a pass" in the conversation of life can be described as impassive.

column3: (adj.) marked by precise accordance with details
column4: People who are meticulous can be pretty annoying, what with their extreme attention to detail. But if that person is, say, your surgeon or your accountant, you'll want them to be meticulous.

column3: (adj.) similar or equivalent in some respects
column4: Upgrades are analogous to an improving credit score, typically allowing bonds to carry a lower interest rate.

column3: (v.) be adjacent or come together
column4: Use the verb converge to describe something that comes together at a common point: “Thousands of Elvis fans plan to converge on the small Arkansas town where unconfirmed sightings of the deceased superstar eating at a local barbeque restaurant had been widely reported.”

column3: (v.) call forth, as an emotion, feeling, or response
column4: A good comedian elicits a lot of laughs.

column3: (v.) be a hindrance or obstacle to
column4: To impede something is to delay or block its progress or movement. Carrying six heavy bags will impede your progress if you're trying to walk across town.

column3: (n.) someone who dislikes people in general
column4: A misanthrope is a person who hates or mistrusts other people. Your great aunt Edna who lashes out at anyone who approaches, convinced they'll steal the jewelry she keeps in her handbag on her lap? A misanthrope indeed.

column3: (n.) a state of lawlessness and disorder
column4: Use the noun anarchy to describe a complete lack of government — or the chaotic state of affairs created by such an absence. A substitute teacher might worry that an unruly classroom will descend into anarchy.

column3: (adj.) rolled longitudinally upon itself
column4: If something is convoluted, it's intricate and hard to understand. You'll need to read over your brother's convoluted investment scheme a few times before deciding whether or not to go in on it.

column3: (v.) make more attractive, as by adding ornament or color
column4: The word "bell" shows up in the middle of embellish, and bells are something that decorate, or embellish something, making it more attractive.

column3: (adj.) preventing especially liquids to pass or diffuse through
column4: If you have a waterproof raincoat, you could say that your coat is impermeable to the rain.

column3: (v.) lessen or to try to lessen the seriousness or extent of
column4: You can mitigate your parents' anger by telling them you were late to dinner because you were helping your elderly neighbor.

column3: (adj.) deviating from the general or common order or type
column4: Something anomalous can be good, such as an exciting new direction in music or art. But that anomalously low score on your math test? Not so good.

column3: (n.) lacking even the rudiments of courage; abjectly fearful
column4: Worse yet, Steve’s pretending not to know what he is doing, which is both disingenuous and craven.

column3: (adj.) derived from experiment and observation rather than theory
column4: “But unfortunately, the empirical evidence is not very clear in terms of explaining any links between media exposure and violent crime.”

column3: (adj.) marked by extreme calm and composure
column4: If your goal is to be imperturbable, then you can't let things bother you or get you stressed, confused, or angry.

column3: (v.) cause to be more favorably inclined
column4: Tsai’s administration may have used the request to mollify hardliners in her Democratic Progressive Party, Wu said.

column3: (n.) a feeling of intense dislike
column4: It found that men with antipathy toward gays had higher arousal levels than men who were accepting of gays.

column3: (v.) cause to lose courage
column4: The Cowardly Lion in the Wizard of Oz appeared at first to be easily daunted, but, in fact, he showed unusual courage.

column3: (v.) strive to equal or match, especially by imitating
column4: He is emulating the skating skills of his older sister.

column3: (adj.) not admitting of passage or capable of being affected
column4: His steely personality made him impervious to jokes about his awful haircut.

column3: (adj.) extremely gloomy and depressed
column4: When someone is morose, they seem to have a cloud of sadness hanging over them.

column3: (n.) an absence of emotion or enthusiasm
column4: You might feel apathy for the political process after watching candidates bicker tediously with one another.

column3: (n.) proper and polite behavior
column4: If you let out a big belch at a fancy dinner party, you're not showing much decorum.

column3: (adj.) native to or confined to a certain region
column4: The area suffers from endemic drug abuse and violent crime.

column3: (adj.) incapable of being appeased or pacified
column4: If you really offended your best friend and tried every kind of apology but she refused to speak to you again, you could describe her as implacable.

column3: (adj.) found in the ordinary course of events
column4: An ordinary, unexciting thing can be called mundane: "Superman hid his heroic feats by posing as his mundane alter ego, Clark Kent.

column3: (vt.) make peace with
column4: Military has periodically tried to appease sentiment on Okinawa.

column3: (n.) an option that is selected automatically
column4: You weren't sure why your new TV kept returning to the factory defaults until you realized you were sitting on the remote.

column3: (v.) weaken mentally or morally
column4: A three-hour lecture on the history of socks might thrill someone, it would enervate most people.

column3: (adj.) suggested though not directly expressed
column4: You might think you and your boyfriend might have an implicit understanding that you are going to get married, but it's probably better to talk it through.

column3: (v.) make ineffective by counterbalancing the effect of
column4: Hanging a disco ball from your living room ceiling negates the sleek modern effect created by the contemporary furniture.

column3: (v.) inform somebody of something
column4: If someone in your immediate family wins the mega-bucks lottery, you want to be the first one to be apprised of that event!

column3: (n.) courteous regard for people's feelings
column4: Sure you wear ripped jeans to school every day, but you don't wear them to your grandmother's house out of deference to her.

column3: (v.) make children; to make happen
column4: You engender the spirit of teamwork and cooperation by encouraging others and doing your share of the group's work.

column3: (v.) burst inward
column4: With extremely large buildings, it helps to implode them rather than explode them, because by falling inward they take up less space.

column3: (n.) any new participant in some activity
column4: While no longer a soccer neophyte, the United States knows it remains a distance from the top tier.

column3: (n.) official approval
column4: A princess, for example, might only consider marrying a prince that is met with her father's, the King's, approbation.

column3: (v.) represented accurately or precisely
column4: “It is essential that the lines between these genres are clear, well delineated and communicated to the audience,” says Leen.

column3: (v.) represented accurately or precisely
column4: University officials contend that having a sizable number of minorities enrolled exposes students to varied perspectives and enhances the educational experience for all students.

column3: (adv.) without knowledge or intention
column4: I inadvertently took someone else's coat from the coatroom because it looked just like mine.

column3: (adj.) stubbornly persistent in wrongdoing
column4: “Why do you wear that stuff?” she was asked, a question that has passed between many a caviling mother and obdurate teenage daughter.

column3: (adj.) suitable for a particular person, place, or situation
column4: A sweater-vest with reindeer on it is appropriate holiday apparel, even if it's totally embarrassing.

column3: (vt.) charge falsely or with malicious intent
column4: As we continue to urge our allies to do more, denigrating our closest partners as liabilities is a serious and tragic mistake,

column3: (adj.) anything short-lived, as an insect that lives only for a day
column4: Something that is fleeting or short-lived is ephemeral, like a fly that lives for one day or text messages flitting from cellphone to cellphone.

column3: (adj.) only partly in existence; imperfectly formed
column4: You can have an inchoate idea, like the earliest flickers of images for your masterpiece, or an inchoate feeling, like your inchoate sense of annoyance toward your sister's new talking parrot.

column3: (adj.) attempting to win favor from influential people by flattery
column4: In prison, Hitler, after jettisoning thoughts of suicide, once again took advantage of the obsequious behavior of his jailers.

column3: (adj.) characterized by effort to the point of exhaustion
column4: Use the adjective, arduous, to describe an activity that takes a lot of effort.

column3: (v.) treat or speak of with contempt
column4: The verb deride means to show a low opinion of someone or something. The jerk would deride the other kids on the bus by calling them names or pulling their hair.

column3: (n.) steadiness of mind under stress
column4: If you take the news of your parakeet's death with equanimity, it means you take it calmly without breaking down.

column3: (n.) the quality of disagreeing
column4: The art show patrons couldn't help but chuckle at the incongruity of a toilet sitting in the middle of an exhibition of Renaissance paintings.

column3: (v.) do away with
column4: If you want to obviate the possibility of a roach infestation, clean your kitchen regularly.

column3: (adj.) simple and natural; without cunning or deceit
column4: "I thought you knowed everything, father, " said the artless boy.

column3: (n.) a financial instrument whose value is based on another security
column4: Kirchner is facing criminal charges over the central bank’s alleged illegal trading of derivatives, while prosecutors also are exploring allegations of money laundering.

column3: (v.) be deliberately ambiguous or unclear
column4: When you are unwilling to make a decision and almost intentionally go back and forth between two choices, you are equivocating. When politicians equivocate, they are often afraid of upsetting, and thus alienating, voters with their decisions.

column3: (adj.) lacking worth or importance
column4: He said in various other interviews that the missed votes were “not a big deal” and that many were “inconsequential.”

column3: (v.) block passage through
column4: Heart surgeons are looking for occlusions in blood vessels––things that occlude the flow of blood.

column3: (adj.) someone who practices self denial as a spiritual discipline
column4: Want to live an ascetic lifestyle? Then you better ditch the flat panel TV and fuzzy slippers. To be ascetic, you learn to live without; it's all about self-denial.

column3: (v.) lacking vitality or spirit; lifeless
column4: The verb desiccate means to dry out, dry up and dehydrate. It's helpful to desiccate weeds but certainly not crops.

column3: (adj.) having or showing profound knowledge
column4: If you call someone erudite, that means they show great learning. After you've earned your second Ph.D., you will be truly erudite.

column3: (v.) make into a whole or make part of a whole
column4: The future tests are likely to incorporate surcharges on the biggest banks because of their systemic importance.

column3: (adj.) intrusive in a meddling or offensive manner
column4: Though officious sounds like official, it means being annoyingly eager to do more than is required. "The officious lunch lady made everyone's food choices her business, and made nasty comments when students chose cookies over carrots."

column3: (adj.) marked by care and persistent effort
column4: Such expertise comes not from luck but from thousands of hours of assiduous effort.

column3: (adj.) marked by lack of definite plan or regularity or purpose
column4: The best news from this desultory referendum campaign is that Brown’s video has gone viral.

column3: (adj.) understandable only by an enlightened inner circle
column4: The quantum theory is not just an esoteric addendum.

column3: (adj.) not fixed or known in advance
column4: When someone contracts a rare stomach parasite but has not been traveling internationally, you might say it had indeterminate origins.

column3: (adj.) very difficult to deal with or do; wearing
column4: But if all of your teachers do it, that makes the task of completing your homework an onerous one, to say the least.

column3: (v.) provide physical relief, as from pain
column4: Assuaging your hunger by eating a bag of marshmallows may cause you other unpleasant feelings.

column3: (n.) something immaterial that interferes with action or progress
column4: Let's say there's a giant pile of cookies being guarded by an angry dog — the dog is a deterrent.

column3: (n.) a formal expression of praise for someone who has died
column4: A year ago this month, President Obama was delivering a eulogy in Charleston, S.C., after the mass shooting in a church there.

column3: (n.) a state of extreme poverty or destitution
column4: If you experience indigence, you have a critical need for food, money, and other resources.

column3: (n.) a state of extreme dishonor
column4: If you throw a soft drink off the theater balcony, the opprobrium might keep you from getting dates to the movies.

column3: (v.) become weaker, in strength, value, or magnitude
column4: The effects of aging may be attenuated by exercise (or by drinking from the fountain of youth).

column3: (n.) thunderous verbal attack
column4: It's pretty overwhelming when you ask your friend a seemingly innocuous question, like "Do you like hot dogs?" and she unleashes a diatribe about the evils of eating meat.

column3: (n.) an inoffensive expression substituted for an offensive one
column4: There’s a euphemism that many in the gaming community use to describe the sometimes intense emotions around gaming: “Passion.”

column3: (adj.) disinclined to work or exertion
column4: It can take an indolent teenager hours to get out of bed on a weekend morning. Often it's noon before he finally comes shuffling down to breakfast in his pajamas.

column3: (v.) move or swing from side to side regularly
column4: On a hot day, you’ll be happy to have a fan that can oscillate, meaning it moves back and forth in a steady motion.

column3: (adj.) disposed to venture or take risks
column4: This adjective is very bold — if you are audacious, you are daring and unconventional!

column3: (n.) being twofold
column4: A dichotomy is an idea or classification split in two. When you point out a dichotomy, you draw a clear distinction between two things.

column3: (v.) make worse
column4: If you're in trouble, complaining about it will only exacerbate the problem.

column3: (adj.) unable to move or resist motion
column4: In most cases, the final polyethylenes are inert and stubbornly resistant to breakdown.

column3: (adj.) intended to attract notice and impress others
column4: The decor reflects the ostentatious style which was fashionable at the time, a mishmash of Neoclassicism and late Renaissance.

column3: (adj.) of a stern or strict bearing or demeanor
column4: In the evenings, as the sun set and the shooting let up, Nott taught his course on surgery in austere environments.

column3: (n.) lack of self-confidence
column4: Your diffidence might be the reason why you never say "hi" to the cute guy or gal in the elevator or why you never ask for a raise.

column3: (v.) pronounce not guilty of criminal charges
column4: If you've been wrongly accused of robbery, you'd better hope a judge will exculpate you, unless you want to go to jail because you've heard prison food is amazing.

column3: (n.) liver or meat or fowl finely minced or ground and variously seasoned
column4: Pate (the food!) is sometimes served with bread or crackers.

column3: (adj.) lacking in sophistication or worldliness
column4: One of the things kindergarten teachers value is the chance to work with kids while they're still relatively ingenuous––their open, trusting natures are a joy.

column3: (adj.) a perfect embodiment of a concept
column4: The downtown area is a paragon for urban renewal, the locals are proud and hospitable, and, most importantly, the city boasts a kick-ass beer scene.

column3: (adj.) a perfect embodiment of a concept
column4: Once you move out of your parents' house and get your own job, you will be an autonomous member of the family.

column3: (adj.) spread out; not concentrated in one place
column4: If lots of people in school believe invisible angels are everywhere, you could say that opinion is diffuse.

column3: (n.) a pressing or urgent situation
column4: Many patients struggle in their role as women, something that has taken on a particular exigency because of drastic changes in gender dynamics.

column3: (adj.) existing as an essential constituent or characteristic
column4: Anticipating how much our tastes will change is hard because we cannot see past our inherent resistance to the unfamiliar.

column3: (adj.) a fervent and even militant proponent of something
column4: If something is prejudicial towards a particular point of view, you can call it partisan. You'll often hear of the partisan politics in the U.S.— since politicians seem to be completely devoted to the agendas of their own parties.

column3: (v.) to declare or affirm solemnly and formally as true
column4: Ultimately, they aver, neuroscience can indeed change our minds — but social and political understanding of the issues must be factored in.

column3: (n.) a turning aside
column4: When your essay about French cooking starts describing a childhood trip to Disneyland, it's taken a digression — it's strayed from the main topic.

column3: (n.) an inference about the future based on known facts
column4: His extrapolation of broad support among minorities appears to be based on one of two cases of violence by minorities against his protesters.

column3: (adj.) not injurious to physical or mental health
column4: Public figures like mayors and governors have to expect they'll get critical or even hurtful emails and phone calls, as well as more innocuous feedback.

column3: (adj.) relating to the study of diseases
column4: There is a pathological gambling addiction so that no matter what he thought at the end of the day, he bet it all.

column3: (adj.) repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse
column4: And his life is just one painfully banal blow after another.

column3: (n.) As you might imagine, a dirge is usually quite sad. Another word with a similar meaning that you might know is “requiem.”
column4: Many cultures have linked weddings with death, often in the form of a bridal dirge about saying farewell to the family.

column3: (adj.) cleverly amusing in tone
column4: Back in the 1920s, the writer Karel Capek said Cesko was “not musical”; for foreigners “it even sounds a little facetious.”

column3: (adj.) barely able to be perceived
column4: The adjective insensible is used to describe someone who is unconscious. If you keep your bowling ball on the top shelf of the closet and it rolls out and conks you on the head, you will be probably rendered insensible.

column3: (n.) an insufficient quantity or number
column4: Given the relative paucity of hotels in the area, many England fans are expected to stay in Lille — a bigger city about 25 miles away.

column3: (v.) be in contradiction with
column4: If you are 93 but look like you are 53, then your young looks belie your age.

column3: (v.) free somebody from an erroneous belief
column4: Many teachers of health find that when they teach, they spend as much energy disabusing kids of false beliefs as they do giving them the facts.

column3: (v.) make easier
column4: If your best friend is very shy, you could facilitate her efforts to meet new people.

column3: (v.) suggest in an indirect or covert way; give to understand
column4: He insinuated that Muslim Americans, like Mexican Americans, were disloyal.

column3: (adj.) marked by a narrow focus on or display of learning
column4: Part of what keeps the sorority girls’ feminist teachings from ever feeling pedantic is that they’re not aimed, at least directly, at the audience.

column3: (adj.) doing or producing good
column4: If you're a beneficent person, you probably spend a lot of your time volunteering at soup kitchens or homeless shelters, helping people who are less fortunate than you are.

column3: (adj.) having or revealing keen insight and good judgment
column4: Discerning people pick up on subtle traits and are good judges of quality — they're the ones that can tell if your cupcakes are homemade from the finest ingredients or totally from a box mix.

column3: (adj.) containing or based on incorrect reasoning
column4: Something fallacious is a mistake that comes from too little information or unsound sources.  Predictions that the whole state of California will snap off from the rest of North America and float away have proven to be fallacious — for now, anyway.

column3: (adj.) lacking in flavor or interest
column4: Something insipid is lacking in flavor or interest.

column3: (n.) a strong liking
column4: If you have a penchant for hot pot, you either eat it daily, or wish you did.

column3: (v.) support and strengthen
column4: When you cheer up a friend who's feeling down, you bolster them.

column3: (adj.) not in agreement or harmony
column4: If you believe that movies should entertain, but your friend insists that movies should inspire, then the two of you hold discordant views on the purpose of movies.

column3: (adj.) devoid of intelligence
column4: In response, the board majority and its industry overlords have offered some of the most fatuous defenses heard from a public body in years.

column3: (n.) the state of being isolated or detached
column4: For centuries, Britain has been a sort of diluted Japan: an island on the edge of a great continental mass, proud of its insularity.

column3: (n.) a state of extreme poverty or destitution
column4: Economic downturns, job loss, shopping sprees, and weekends at the high rollers' table in Vegas can lead to penury.

column3: (adj.) ostentatiously lofty in style
column4: Apple’s political stand against Trump, communicated privately to Republicans, is a sign of the widening schism between Silicon Valley and the GOP’s bombastic presumptive nominee.

column3: (n.) the state of being held in low esteem
column4: “your actions will bring discredit to your name”

column3: (adj.) attempting to win favor by flattery
column4: WoW is so popular that there are professional players who are treated like movie stars, complete with sponsorship deals with fawning groupies.

column3: (adj.) difficult to manage or mold
column4: Can't manage your stubborn little brother who won't do what anyone says? You could call him intractable.

column3: (adj.) lasting three seasons or more
column4: If you fight with your parents every year over whether they really must invite your annoying cousins for Thanksgiving, you could call that a perennial conflict.

column3: (adj.) ill-mannered and coarse in behavior or appearance
column4: If your cousin tells revolting jokes, belches, and smells like he spent the winter in a cave, he could be described as boorish — an adjective used for people with bad manners and a sloppy appearance.

column3: (n.) a difference between conflicting facts or claims or opinions
column4: If there is a discrepancy between the money you earned and the number on your paycheck, you should complain to your boss.

column3: (adj.) exhibiting an agreeably appropriate manner or style
column4: Felicitous words you write on your friend's birthday card are the ones that perfectly suit the occasion and make her happy when she reads them.

column3: (n.) stubborn refusal to compromise or change
column4: If you refuse to compromise with your sister about whose turn it is to do the dishes, your mother might accuse you both of intransigence.

column3: (adj.) tending to betray
column4: My view was that Pakistan was playing a perfidious and dangerous double game and needed to be called on it.

column3: (n.) grow and flourish
column4: If you have a green thumb, in the spring your flower gardens may burgeon. If you don't have a green thumb, your collection of plastic plants may burgeon.

column3: (n.) feelings of great warmth and intensity
column4: Use fervor to describe an intensity of emotion or expression. Fans of the Los Angeles Dodgers show so much fervor that they "bleed Dodger blue."

column3: (v.) fill or cover completely, usually with water
column4: Your bathroom could be inundated with water if the pipes burst, and hopefully your inbox is inundated with nice emails on your birthday.

column3: (adj.) hasty and without attention to detail; not thorough
column4: If you give someone a gift and they look at it like it's roadkill and say nothing about it but a perfunctory "thank you," you might not be giving them another one anytime soon.

column3: (v.) polish and make shine
column4: The young man burnishes his Porsche until it seems to gleam with pride.

column3: (adj.) not straightforward or candid
column4: “The prime minister has led a very disingenuous campaign on the most crucial question our country will face in my lifetime,” he said.

column3: (n.) a rectangular piece of cloth of distinctive design
column4: The coffins were draped in the Bangladeshi flag – a red disc on a green background.

column3: (adj.) allowing fluids or gases to pass or diffuse through
column4: I wish I hadn't worn my permeable sweater to the picnic when the weatherman called for thunderstorms. The rain seeped right through the fabric, soaking me to the skin.

column3: (n.) a support usually of stone or brick (v.)  make stronger or defensible
column4: You may find that giving compliments to everyone you meet buttresses your popularity.

column3: (adj.) unaffected by concern for one's own welfare
column4: If you can't decide whether to purchase the shirt with orange polka dots or the purple paisley-patterned one, you might seek input from a disinterested, or unbiased, party (who will probably tell you not to buy either one).

column3: (n.) young bird that has just fledged or become capable of flying
column4: The Guardian’s Beijing correspondent asks if Britain’s fledgling “golden relationship” with China could be in jeopardy.

column3: (n.) abusive language used to express blame or censure
column4: Invective is harsh, abusive language, like, "you dirty rotten scoundrel.

column3: (adj.) spreading or spread throughout
column4: But how did asking "what's trending?" become such a pervasive online trend?

column3: (adj.) having an unpleasant sound
column4: The lyrical streets, colorful personalities, and cacophonous eateries are practically extinct.

column3: (adj.) taken apart at the points of connection
column4: But she did not want too many more of those moments, because they shifted her balance, left her spirit vaguely disjointed.

column3: (v.) treat with contemptuous disregard
column4: In an interview on Wisconsin television this week, Ryan said he would not allow Democrats to continue flouting the rules of the House.

column3: (adj.) quickly aroused to anger
column4: If you're irascible, you get angry easily — perhaps blowing up in rage when someone brushes into you.

column3: (adj.) showing little emotion
column4: People who are phlegmatic are just a little dull in expressing feelings or showing emotion.

column3: (adj.) determined by chance or impulse rather than by necessity
column4: Capricious is an adjective to describe a person or thing that's impulsive and unpredictable, like a bride who suddenly leaves her groom standing at the wedding altar.

column3: (v.) stop associating with
column4: At the end of a lesson period, your teacher says, "class dismissed.

column3: (vt.) try to stir up
column4: Russia has nurtured discord inside the European Union by supporting an array of small, extremist political parties that foment nationalist anger in different countries.

column3: (adj.) uncertain how to act or proceed
column4: Irresolute describes someone who feels stuck.

column3: (n.) righteousness by virtue of being pious
column4: Piety is devotion to God or to religious practices. Nuns who pray all day long are famous for their piety. If you have filial piety it means you're devoted to your parents.

column3: (n.) verbal punishment
column4: If your coach yells at your team for sloppy play, his post-game speech might be called a castigation.

column3: (vt.) express a negative opinion of
column4: If you haven't got anything nice to say, then it's time to disparage someone. It means to belittle or degrade a person or idea.

column3: (vt.) keep from happening or arising; make impossible
column4: To forestall the effects of aging, exercise and take care of your health all your life.

column3: (n.) an established line of travel or access
column4: An itinerary is your travel plan — where you will go and when you will be there.

column3: (vt.) cause to be more favorably inclined
column4: When a husband shows up with flowers after he's fought with his wife, he's trying to placate her.

column3: (n.) substance that initiates or accelerates a chemical reaction
column4: A catalyst is an event or person causing a change. Getting kicked out of your parents' house might be a catalyst for becoming more independent.

column3: (adj.) fundamentally different or distinct in quality or kind
column4: The trunk of some people's cars may contain items as disparate as old clothes, rotting food, and possibly a missing relative.

column3: (n.) prudence in avoiding waste
column4: If you try to avoid waste by reusing and repurposing items that most people would throw away, your frugality will save you money.

column3: (adj.) brief and to the point
column4: Laconic is an adjective that describes a style of speaking or writing that uses only a few words, often to express complex thoughts and ideas.

column3: (n.) the property of being physically malleable
column4: Plasticity means "changeability" or "moldability" — clay has a lot of plasticity, but a rock has almost none.

column3: (adj.)capable of destroying or eating away by chemical action
column4: The lawsuits have, at times, devolved into a war of words, with both sides releasing caustic statements.

column3: (v.) behave unnaturally or affectedly; to deceive
column4: When confronted about their human rights record, the Chinese government typically dissembles.

column3: (adj.) producing no result or effect
column4: Hopefully all the time you're spending studying vocabulary won't turn out to be futile!

column3: (n.) a feeling of lack of interest or energy
column4: If you are feeling lassitude, you're weary and just can't be bothered. Couch potatoes make lassitude into an art form

column3: (n.) a trite or obvious remark
column4: His employees might get sick of listening to these meaningless clichés and tell him to cut the platitudes.

column3: (n.) extreme excess
column4: If you have 15 different people who want to take you on a date, you have a plethora of romantic possibilities.

column3: (v.) make peace with
column4: If you forgot flowers on your Mom's birthday, you can still propitiate her by sending a bouquet the next day.

column3: (v.) cancel officially
column4: Carter made it known last July that he intended to rescind the ban on transgender service members serving in the military, calling it outdated.

column3: (adj.) recurring in scattered or unpredictable instances
column4: The mail carrier comes every day but the plumber's visits are sporadic––he comes as needed.

column3: (adj.) easily managed
column4: If your little brother quietly obeys your instructions and waits for you at the food court while you and your friends wander around the mall, he's probably a tractable child, meaning he's obedient, flexible, and responds well to directions.

column3: (v.) drop sharply
column4: The verb plummet means "to drop sharply, like eagles that plummet toward earth, seeking prey, or school attendance that plummets when there is a flu outbreak.

column3: (n.) correct behavior
column4: If you are someone who cares about always doing the right and proper thing, your friends might accuse you of being obsessed with propriety and beg you to loosen up.

column3: (n.) a decision to do something or to behave in a certain manner
column4: Israeli officials have repeatedly said Arab nations band together to propose resolutions that impact Israel at the U.N.

column3: (n.) a symbol of disgrace or infamy
column4: If something has a negative association attached to it, call this a stigma.

column3: (n.) the violation of a law or a duty or moral principle
column4: Whether you are cheating on a test, or cheating on a spouse, you are committing transgressions that are not easily forgiven.

column3: (adj.) full of holes or vessels
column4: A sponge is porous, and if the border between countries is open for anyone to cross easily, it too can be called porous.

column3: (v.) command against
column4: To proscribe something is to forbid or prohibit it, as a school principal might proscribe the use of cell phones in class.

column3: (vt.) find a solution or answer
column4: A college's board of directors might resolve to recruit more minority students.

column3: (n.) supply sparingly and with restricted quantities
column4: The rookie was recalled earlier Sunday from Triple-A Scranton/Wilkes-Barre, his third stint with the big league team this year.

column3: (n.) obstreperous and defiant aggressiveness
column4: If you get into fights all of the time, you might be accused of truculence and sent for anger management classes.

column3: (adj.) concerned with practical matters
column4: She has proved to be an effective and pragmatic leader.

column3: (adj.) strong and sharp
column4: Use pungent to describe a taste or smell that gives a sharp sensation. "The atmosphere was pungent with the odor of stale sweat."

column3: (adj.) quiet, restrained, reluctant to draw attention to yourself
column4: Reticent means either quiet or restrained. If you're reticent about your feelings, you like to keep them to yourself, and you're probably quiet in rowdy groups where everyone is talking over each other.

column3: (v.) make an express demand or provision in an agreement
column4: To stipulate something means to demand that it be part of an agreement. When you make a contract or deal, you can stipulate that a certain condition must be met.

column3: (v.) be undecided about something
column4: You might vacillate between ordering waffles and pancakes at your favorite diner — it’s hard to pick just one when both are so tasty!

column3: (n.) a brief introduction to a speech or constitution
column4: It seemed clear this circling was the preamble to something worse.

column3: (adj.) feeling or showing profound respect or veneration
column4: When you have great awe and respect for someone or something, and you show it by respectfully worshiping that person, thing, deity, or musical group, you are being reverent.

column3: (adj.) having or revealing little emotion or sensibility
column4: A stolid person can’t be moved to smile or show much sign of life, in much the same way as something solid, like a giant boulder, is immovable.

column3: (v.) regard with feelings of respect and reverence
column4: Fini said, he wants to call as a witness the Falun Gong’s venerated founder and leader, Li Hongzhi.

column3: (adj.) not secure; beset with difficulties
column4: Grab for the adjective precarious when something is unstable, dangerous or difficult and likely to get worse. Are you totally broke and the people you owe money to keep calling? You're in a precarious financial situation!

column3: (v.) pick a mini-fight over something that doesn't really matter.
column4: Let's not quibble over price," people will say, usually when they plan to gouge you.

column3: (n.) a mentor in spiritual and philosophical topics
column4: Thanks to the sage advice of your friend, you didn't write your teacher an angry e-mail!

column3: (v.) mark with stripes
column4: Since planning this Utah vacation, I had been coming across aerial photos of a gooseneck turn in the Colorado River that weaves among striated cliffs.

column3: (adj.) habitually speaking the truth
column4: Someone who is veracious speaks the truth — like your brutally honest friend who always lets you know what she thinks about your outfits, your hairstyle, your lasagna recipe, and your taste in movies.

column3: (v.) bring about abruptly
column4: Precipitate usually means "bringing something on" or "making it happen" — and not always in a good way.

column3: (adj.) being quiet or still or inactive
column4: Sandy enjoys the quiescent moments lying in a hammock on a beautiful summer Sunday.

column3: (adj.) promoting health; healthful
column4: Salubrious is a fancy way to describe something that’s good for you or is generally favorable to mind or body, but it need not be limited to describing healthy foods or liquids.

column3: (v.) to walk with a lofty proud gait
column4: When you strut, you walk with a proud swagger that has a little arrogance thrown in, like the prance of a running back who has just flown past the 250-pound linebackers and planted the ball in the end zone.

column3: (adj.) using or containing too many words
column4: If you're verbose, you use far more words than you need to.

column3: (n.) something indicating the approach of something or someone
column4: Pride is a precursor to the fall.

column3: (adj.) of high moral or intellectual value
column4: Use the adjective rarefied to describe things that are so stylish, smart, or moral that they seem elevated above the ordinary, like the rarefied conversation of brilliant scholars.

column3: (n.) official permission or approval; the act of punishing
column4: Sanction has two nearly opposite meanings: to sanction can be to approve of something, but it can also mean to punish, or speak harshly to.

column3: (n.) a writ issued to compel the attendance of a witness
column4: A subpoena is a document that requires its recipient to appear in court as a witness.

column3: (adj.) capable of life or normal growth and development
column4: A viable seed can develop into a plant, while a viable company has the resources to succeed.

column3: (adj.) excessively forward
column4: While it would be “presumptuous” to agree, “If memory serves, when I started out all color was absent from fashion,” he added.

column3: (adj.) stubbornly resistant to authority or control
column4: Meanwhile, the National Liberation Army, a much smaller but more recalcitrant rebel group, hasn't started peace talks.

column3: (v.) fill to satisfaction
column4: If you just can't get enough popcorn, even the jumbo tub at the movie theater may not be enough to satiate, or satisfy, your desire.

column3: (v.) sink to a lower level or form a depression
column4: Now, even as the market panic subsides, Brexit is raising existential questions about London’s future as one of the world’s great financial capitals.

column3: (adj.) having a relatively high resistance to flow
column4: If something is viscous, you usually don't want to stick your fingers in it — that goes for boogers and maple syrup alike.

column3: (v.) be deliberately ambiguous or unclear
column4: When you prevaricate, you lie or mislead.

column3: (v.) formally reject or disavow a formerly held belief
column4: He recanted within hours, saying that doctors who perform abortions should be held legally responsible;

column3: (v.) infuse or fill completely
column4: A heavy rainstorm can saturate the ground, leaving puddles on the lawn because no more water can be absorbed.

column3: (v.) establish or strengthen as with new evidence or facts
column4: We’d really like to believe in the Tooth Fairy; however, more evidence is needed to substantiate her existence (besides that quarter in your pocket).

column3: (adj.) marked by harshly abusive criticism
column4: Use the adjective vituperative to describe criticism that's so sharp it hurts.

column3: (adj.) immaculately clean and unused
column4: Please check your shoes before walking on a pristine white carpet...

column3: (n.) one who lives in solitude
column4: Dickinson is often portrayed as some white gossamer recluse, completely divorced from the world outside her bedroom—but that is not really true.

column3: (v.) the taste experience when a savoury condiment is tasted
column4: Whether it’s a feeling of joy or a piece of pecan pie — when you savor something, you enjoy it to the fullest.

column3: (v.) take the place or move into the position of
column4: And the Supreme Court has held that national-party rules supercede State laws.

column3: (adj.) liable to lead to sudden change or violence
column4: Watch out when a situation becomes volatile — it is likely to change for the worse suddenly.

column3: (n.) complete and confirmed integrity
column4: I am a model of probity and people find my presence reassuring.

column3: (adj.) difficult to penetrate; incomprehensible to one of ordinary understanding or knowledge
column4: Then again, it was impressive to witness the intense interest that this recondite author still arouses.

column3: (vt.) generate and separate from cells or bodily fluids
column4: When you squeeze a lemon, it secretes juice.

column3: (n.) a guess or hypothesis
column4: Your supposition that your kids will automatically wash their hands before dinner is probably false. You'd best remind them to do it or risk dirty hands at dinner.

column3: (adj.) incapable of being justified or explained
column4: He singled out major research hospitals for poor collaboration and drug companies for unwarranted price hikes.

column3: (adj.) making great mental demands
column4: Metro station design and function will continue to be problematic.

column3: (adj.) stubbornly resistant to authority or control
column4: The dog is refractory, or stubbornly resisting your authority.

column3: (n.) a broken piece of a brittle artifact
column4: If you break a mirror, the thin sharp pieces you want to avoid are shards.

column3: (adj.) implied by or inferred from actions or statements
column4: Something tacit is implied or understood without question. Holding hands might be a tacit acknowledgment that a boy and girl are dating.

column3: (adj.) marked by keen caution and watchful prudence
column4: Be wary of risky things like wild mushrooms and Internet deals!

column3: (adj.) recklessly wasteful
column4: Use the adjective prodigal to describe someone who spends too much money, or something very wasteful.

column3: (v.) overthrow by argument, evidence, or proof
column4: When the kids you're babysitting swear they brushed their teeth, you can refute their claim by presenting the dry toothbrushes.

column3: (n.) someone who habitually doubts accepted beliefs
column4: A skeptic is a doubter. The guy who's ready to poke holes in the most brilliant argument you've ever made.

column3: (adj.) of superficial relevance if any
column4: Granot said African countries may be responsive to supporting Israel because the Palestinian cause is "tangential" to them.

column3: (n.) a confused multitude of things
column4: Use the noun welter to describe an enormous, messy pile, like the jumble of papers, coffee mugs, pens, and food wrappers on the desk of the messiest person in the office.

column3: (v.) assign to a lower position
column4: If the quarterback of the football team stops making decent throws he might be relegated to the position of benchwarmer, while another kid is given the chance to play.

column3: (adj.) very thin in gauge or diameter
column4: If you try to learn a complicated mathematical concept by cramming for 45 minutes, you will have a tenuous grasp of that concept, at best.

column3: (adj.) tending to discourage, especially of prices
column4: If something's so expensive you can't touch it, it's prohibitive. That Ferrari in the showroom? You may want it, but its price is prohibitive.

column3: (n.) mildly criticize
column4: If you show poor manners at your grandmother's dinner table, she will reproach you.

column3: (adj.) sleep inducing
column4: Certain medicines, but also extreme coziness, can have a soporific effect.

column3: (n.) a speech of violent denunciation
column4: A BBC presenter is moved to tears as she describes the racist tirade she faced in Coventry city centre.

column3: (n.) a fervent and even militant proponent of something
column4: The hamburger zealot was so fanatical about his burgers that he camped outside his favorite fast-food joint for hours every morning, waiting for it to open.

column3: (v.) grow rapidly
column4: Bunny rabbits have a habit of proliferating, as do dandelions in untended gardens and funny YouTube videos on the internet.

column3: (n.) a person without moral scruples
column4: There's no way around it, a reprobate is a bad egg.

column3: (adj.) plausible but false
column4: Use specious to describe an argument that seems to be good, correct, or logical, but is not so.

column3: (n.) a state of motor and mental inactivity
column4: After a huge Thanksgiving meal, my family members fall into a torpor; no one can even pick up the TV remote.

column3: (n.) a natural inclination
column4: It is well documented that Bill Clinton has a propensity for being social when he sees someone he knows in public.

column3: (vt.) refuse to acknowledge, ratify, or recognize as valid
column4: At a campaign event in Pittsburgh, Clinton excoriated Trump and challenged Republicans to repudiate him.

column3: (n.) a broad range of related objects or values or qualities
column4: There is a wide spectrum of political beliefs in this country, ranging from super conservative to uber-liberal and everything in between.

column3: (adj.) marked by repeated turns and bends
column4: James Bond drove his custom BMW 120 mph on the road that was tortuous in its twists and turns.

column3: (adj.) constituting a separate entity or part
column4: As her friend drove off, O’Keefe moved her Mustang, which had been parked under a light, to a more discrete spot.

column3: (adj.) meeting the proper standards or requirements for a task
column4: Its hard cheeses are handcrafted in open vats by qualified cheesemakers, not machines.

column3: (adj.) made tough by habitual exposure
column4: If you have gotten so many mosquito bites in your life that they no longer bother you, you have become inured to them.

column3: (adj.) determined by chance or impulse rather than by necessity
column4: This album was largely whimsical and retrospective, with a subtle sense of humour, even through the more serious numbers.

column3: (adj.) full of anxiety and concern
column4: When you hear the word solicitous, think of your mom — attentive, caring, and concerned.
